habitat_description:
The distribution of the Texas lyresnake expands across southwestern New Mexico, western Texas, and neighboring Chihuahua and Coahuila, in Mexico. Populations are well established in many of the Mexican mountain ranges bordering the Rio Grande across Chihuahua and Sierra del Carmen in western Coahuila. The elevational range has been estimated from 860 meters up to 1856 in its highest localities (Le Duc and Johnson 2003). In Southern New Mexico, this snake is found in Dona Ana, Grant, Hidalgo, Luna, and Sierra counties; in Texas, Brewster, Hudspeth, El Paso, Jeff Davis, and Presidio counties (Devitt et al. 2008).

This species burrows in or using soil, but also in fallen logs and decaying vegetation. It occupies areas characterized by bare rock, talus, and scree. Inhabits desert, shrubland, chaparral, conifer, hardwood, mixed woodland (Natureserve.org). It is most commonly found in rocky, dry terrain of mountainous features, canyons, hills, rock outcrops, and other similar conditions. This species is associated with areas dominated by mesquite, catclaw mimosa, ocotillo, lechugilla, yucca, white thorn, prickly pear, native grasses, creosote bush, and cholla (Degenhardt et al. 1996; LaDuc and Johnson 2003; Natureserve.org; Tennant 1998; Werler and Dixon 2000).

SW	-Associated with plant communities of, ocotillo, catclaw mimosa, yucca, prickly pear, cholla, native grasses, white thorn, creosote bush, and trees like mesquite, ash, hackberry, and juniper oak.
